On 6 March 2011 00:22, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Colin,
>
> I think it's pretty reasonable to speculate that some initial "primed" connectivity is
> specified through DNA that then goes through changes according to rules of plasticity. Of
> course, there is probably not a strict "pre-specified" period and another strict "plastic"
> period, because in reality they likely overlap from the very start, but the general idea that
> both elements are present and that the pendulum swings gradually away from
> pre-specification makes sense to me.

Sure.

> From a neuroevolution perspective, it's possible to
> imagine variants of adaptive HyperNEAT that exhibit more or less of this type of dynamic.
> Adaptive HyperNEAT was described in "Indirectly Encoding Neural Plasticity as a Pattern
> of Local Rules," which is at http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.sab10.html . Of
> course we are continuing to explore these types of plastic models.

> About the junk DNA hypothesis - it's the type of thing you can't really definitively verify as
> true or false, but if some initial "randomness" in the brain was provided by junk DNA it
> wouldn't be that surprising. But the thing I kind of object to in the quotations you provided
> is the idea that this idea is "bold." It doesn't seem to me to be a major problem to explain
> how disorganized randonmness can get into a system. I mean, random initialization (which
> is a standard part of many EAs and other learning algorithms) is generally not the
> interesting part, at least not in terms of being the part that requires great intellectual effort
> to conceive or understand. So if nature in fact took one arbitrary route to getting a little
> randomness into things over another, it doesn't seem that impressive or fortuitous
> compared to how it discovered the parts that are, in contrast, well-organized.

So I have a counterpoint to this argument that I'm not 100% sure how
to explain but I'll have a go...

Yes there are various ANN connection weight initialisation methods
some of which employ randomness either by itself or as part of some
broader method. Those techniques (AFAIK) tend to use traditional
random number generators (RNGs) and either uniform or gaussian noise.
I'm suggesting that if nature had a use for this form of randomness
then it would be fairly easy to evolve from scratch and therefore
wouldn't require utilisation of junk DNA. Easy to evolve because the
noise could be said to have low Kolmogorov complexity (can be
generated by a simple algorithm), although I'm not 100% sure how
biologically plausible this part of my argument is.

So assuming for now that nature /is/ using junk DNA as a source of
noise for connection patterns *and* that there is an easier to
discover source, the question becomes - why use junk DNA?

This junk DNA has complexity and structure that had utility in its
origin domain, so as a source of connectivity patterns in this other
unrelated domain it's /effectively/ random, but this is a form of
randomness very much distinct from gaussian noise, it has complex
structure. E.g. consider using bytes from some random portion of
computer RAM as a source of random numbers - it's going to have very
different properties than gaussian noise. Mathematically speaking the
junk DNA noise has a high(er) Kolmogorov complexity (it cannot be
represented by a simple/trivial algorithm as gaussian noise can be).
So yes it's arbitrary but it's also non-trivial to evolve from
scratch, as such it's possible that some properties of this complex
random noise are useful for brains - e.g. maybe when mapped to
connectivity patterns they have a good proportion of short to long
connection lengths (massively oversimplifying how complex this junk
DNA might be here, but maybe that helps explain my argument).

[As a side note all of this sort of fits in with your talk on
serendipity and novelty search]

[As another side note I would also add that if junk DNA is being used
it's likely that it's being used for things other than connectivity
patterns - that's just one hypothesis. We know that this DNA is being
expressed but don't know for sure if it has an utility, it might just
be a side effect of other useful DNA being expressed (holding on for
the ride)]

But if you take on the assumptions I've stated then this has
implications for CPPNs. Currently our CPPNs are mostly using
continuous functions operating on a continuous coordinate space - and
therefore generate continuous/smooth connectivity patterns. Should we
consider inclusing a means of introducing complexity into the patterns
early on that isn't directly evolved? e.g. some new CPPN function that
refers to a chunk of complex random noise? For a laugh we could use
actual junk DNA sequences from nature translated into numbers -
probably as good a source as any :)

Colin.
